newsitem.title: FRANCE: Chirac says will ensure all serve French interests.
newsitem.headline: Chirac says will ensure all serve French interests.

text.p: Gaullist President Jacques Chirac, on his first outing since a parliamentary election obliged him to share power with a leftist government, said on Saturday he would ensure the arrangement served France's best interests.

"Today my duty is to ensure that each has his place and respects the other, and that together we serve the interests and values...that unite us," Chirac told a health care cooperative in the northern city of Lille.

Chirac, who spent the last week closeted in the Elysee presidential palace after a leftist alliance led by Socialist Lionel Jospin swept the previous centre-right majority from power, said the interests and values he referred to included equality of opportunity, civic duty and republican virtue.
His duty was also to "continue to advance, despite the obstacles, towards a Europe that is united, strong and just," he said.
"Today my duty is to ensure that France enters the era of high technology, without which we would be without economic growth and full employment," the French head of state added.

Chirac noted that he had experience in power-sharing or "cohabitation" as he had served as a rightist prime minister under the late Socialist president Francois Mitterrand and thus was able "to appreciate the fundamental role of the president as guardian of our institutions."
